title: We went three times in one week!
text:
Magic Hands Massage is on the famous pedestrian-only Quinta Avenida (Fifth Avenue) in Playa del Carmen between Calle 10 and Calle 12 on the east (Caribbean beach) side.

Look for the tiny reception desk on the sidewalk by the “Playa del Carmen Official Store”; the massage spa is upstairs above the store under the palapa (grass) roof.

At the time of our most recent visit in early March, 2020 a two-hour massage was $50 US; of course we added a 20% ($10 US) tip. Our usual Playa del Carmen resort has great beachside massages and also massages indoors in a beautiful world-class spa. The downside is that they are $200 each for two hours.

Magic Hands is decidedly un-fancy: efficient rather than luxurious. The palapa roof admits quite a bit of Quinta Avenida street noise — pedestrian and vendor chatter, piped music from restaurants, an occasional strolling mariachi band, bird calls, etc. — but after a few minutes it becomes background “white noise”.

We were in Playa for seven days on our most recent trip in March, 2020. We indulged ourselves with THREE two-hour Swedish massages by Nory and Natalia on three different days during that time (and went home feeling like eels, oh so relaxed).

Appointments are recommended; you can send a message via the Magic Hands Massage Face Book page at Send Message.

Highly recommended!

title: Always outstanding
text:
We've visited Mahekal Beach Resort eight times in the past ten years; it has always been good and steadily gets better.

We fly out of Denver and touch down in Cancun. With a transfer from the airport in Cancun to Mahekal, we can breakfast at home in the morning and enjoy dinner at Mahekal in the evening.

We've explored the Yucatan over the years, renting cars and staying in various towns and cities, but we keep coming back to Mahekal.

The staff is great at Mahekal; many of them have worked at the resort longer than we have been visiting. We especially like to see out old friends including Ignacio, Jose, Marcos, Angel, Mariano, the irrepressible Rogelio, and our new friends Mario, Zuri, and Viarnay. They make Mahekal a very special place indeed.

The accommodations are wonderful, food is great (we had breakfast, dinner, and drinks at Fuego in addition to meals in the other two resort restaurants), and the structures and grounds are well-maintained.

Mahekal is safe with round-the-clock security at the entrance and on the beach and also patrolling the resort. The only downside we have ever experienced was external: Extremely loud all-night electronic dance music from a festival at the nearby Mamita's Beach Club a couple of years ago. (Mahekal staff was aware of the problem and apologetic but had no control over Mamita's.)

Enjoy two-for-one Happy Hour drinks from 5 to 6 pm!

title: Quick and easy
text: Pushed back a minute or two early and got into Denver about as early. Great crew! Crowded seating, of course. The aircraft was clean and fairly new.

title: Lively and hip pizza place
text: A short walk from the landmark Syntagma Square is a energetic and popular pizza place. Salads are good and the thin-crust pizza pleases. Insider tip: Sit at a table on the sidewalk and take in the cool city vibes of Athens. Beautiful after dark!

title: Friendly, relaxed, good food
text: The Victory labels itself as a "café - snack - bar" but it is really more of a laid-back full-service restaurant. The tables just off the sidewalk under an awning are shielded just enough by plants that you don't mind the downtown Athens cars and traffic. The owners are super-friendly and the food is good, fresh, and plentiful. In the Plaka neighborhood, it is just a short walk from the Acropolis Museum and and the Acropolis.

title: A wonder of the world!
text: We've been fortunate enough to visit some of the great manmade sites of the world -- Machu Pichu, Tulum, Paris, London, New York City, etc. -- and the Acropolis is a great addition to our list. Not to be missed!

title: Worldclass museum!
text:
We visited the museum -- which is located just below the Acropolis -- after spending a few hours at the Acropolis itself. The museum gave us a great insight into what we had seen just minutes before.

Plan on two hours or so to really immerse yourself in this great contemporary experience.

title: Good food, great friendly service
text:
The "White Horse" café is a tiny hole-in-the-wall place near the Electra Palace Hotel in the Plaka neighborhood, well worth searching out for a friendly, informal lunch or dinner.

The attitude and attention of the charming owner were wonderful and the food was good. The clientele was truly international on the night when we at at Aspro Alogo and everying was having a great time.

Recommmended!

title: A gem!
text:
The Electra Palace is top flight.

Use your smartphone weather app to determine sunset and get a table at the rooftop restaurant about 45 minutes before sunset: You'll have a world-class view of the Acropolis. The sunset is actually best about 15 minutes before the sun goes down.

The sunset and an excellent dinner will make your day one to remember!

We asked for an Acropolis-view room and while it wasn't as spectacular as the rooftop view we watched a beautiful moonset, dramatic nighttime Acropolis lighting, and beautiful early-morning scenes as the sun rose from behind the hotel.

The staff is first-rate and the facility is clean and well-maintained. The rooftop restaurant buffet breakfast is sumptuous -- an insider tip: you can request custom espresso drinks -- the restaurant's bar is friendly, and service is great.

There is a small rooftop pool and a second small indoor pool on the lower spa level.

The location in the charming Plaka neighborhood is just a 15-minute walk from the Acropolis and there are myriad good non-franchise restaurants nearby. A short walk in the other direction gets one to Syntagma Square where you can grab one of the hop-on hop-off buses for an excellent overview of Athens without having to fight the inevitable big-city traffic.

Highly recommended!

title: The TripAdvisor reviews are spot on
text:
Of course there was a line outside when we got there but people were cordial and the complimentary hot chai was warming.

We stuck with the basics: Vegetable Samosas, Kachumber Salad, Raita, Naan Bread, and bowls of Black Daal. The Daal was so unbelievably that one of the first things I did when we got home was to search for a Dishoom Daal recipe. Unsurprisingly, it is a trade secret.

I found a recipe or two that seem to come close to the Dishoom recipe; the best one will be a "keeper" in my recipe file.

The only thing that I regret is that there in no Dishoom in our home town!

title: Superb!
text: Beautiful contemporary property, great location, amazing staff. A truly fine hotel in a city known for excellent lodging. Wonderful variety of delicious restaurants within a block or two. Definitely make the short walk to Covent Garden, an energy magnet for eating, shopping, and people watching.

title: Fun, friendly and informal
text:
While staying at the nearby (and newly-remodeled) Godfrey Hotel for just two days we managed to visit Whiskey Joe's three times, once just for drinks and twice for dinner.

It's a popular place and on weekend afternoons it's mobbed and the parking lot is full. There is overflow parking in the Godfrey Hotel lot but it is $10. Don't worry about a dress code: Heck, it's a beach bar: Think swimsuits and flip-flops.

All of our servers were friendly and professional. One low point was the server who stood near our table and loudly trashed a customer who just left for picking up his credit card but not signing the receipt and leaving a tip. "It's not worth getting upset over $3," another server said to him. Conversations like that should be saved for private time out of the earshot of other customers.

Nevertheless, there are great local beers, good drinks, and respectable food. If we were going back to Tampa we would gladly visit Whiskey Joe's again (and stay at the Godfrey).

title: Great atmosphere, excellent food
text:
We stayed at the nearby and newly-remodeled Godfrey Hotel for a few nights and used TripAdvisor to find a few good restaurants within easy walking distance. The Rusty Pelican came highly recommended and did not disappoint.

Since I generally try to adhere to the Mediterranean Diet with salads and seafoods high in Omega-3's, my wife and I both decided on a salad with grilled Salmon. We placed our orders but were soon told by our server that the chef had rejected the day's Salmon delivery; would we accept a substitution of grilled Grouper for the same price? Why, yes, of course!

The Grouper was perfect and the Seasonal Mixed Greens salads with crinkle-cut pears, grapes, candied walnuts, Bleu cheese, and a subtle vinaigrette were delectable. We washed everything down with San Pellegrino sparking water and a bottle of reasonably-priced Ecco Domani Pinot Grigio white wine.

We were there for dinner relatively early and had a table by the windows with a great view of Pelicans, a very active Osprey, a mother with a procession of baby ducks, and of course the often-mentioned beautiful sunset.

Owen, our server, was gracious and professional without being overbearing. The dining room is beautiful in an upscale way without being pretentious.

The only thing that was a bit off-putting was the fact that there are no sidewalks so pedestrians have to walk in the street. I guess that's a Florida thing because we saw that in other areas as well including outside the main entrance of the Godfrey Hotel. It is not the fault of the businesses, of course, but a definite safety and convenience issue. If you are in a car, have no worries.

If we had another day in Tampa at the Godfrey, we would have revisited the Rusty Pelican.

title: Easy-going kayak experience in Tampa Bay
text:
Since our Tampa hotel, the newly-remodeled Godfrey Hotel, was an easy walk to WhatSUP Paddle Sports, we planned a short kayak trip one afternoon. The afternoon we were there, both of the available solo kayaks were in use so we had a short wait for them to be returned. Apparently, that day there were only two solo kayaks and one two-person kayak available.

We took the kayaks out for two hours -- actually returning them in a little less than 120 minutes -- and found Tampa Bay to be nearly mirror-like with just a slight breeze. The kayaks were nearly new, clean, and in excellent condition.

Some food and drinks are available at the WhatSUP concession at Ben T. Davis Beach and it is only about a ten-minute walk from WhatSUP to the popular Whiskey Joe's Tampa Bar & Grill where we retired for Cuba Libré's after kayaking.

One can book kayaks and standup paddle boards (that's where the 'SUP comes from) online; it might be a good idea to do that in advance so the kayaks are ready when you are. WhatSUP also takes credit cards so the rental transaction is quick and easy.

A very friendly nature experience!

title: A Boulder favorite
text: Consistently a first-place winner in several restaurant categories in Boulder Weekly's annual "Best of Boulder", The Med is a vibrant tapas or small plate restaurant. The energy is high, the service amazingly fast, and prices reasonable. Outdoor seating on the patio is wonderful.

title: Where the locals go
text:
If you are staying at the amazing Hotel Boulderado and want a break from the high energy of Boulder's Pearl Street Mall and its associated restaurants -- don't get me wrong: many are very good indeed -- a ten-minute walk will take you to The Hungry Toad, a low-key locally-owned Boulder institution for some twenty-six years.

The food is "pub grub" to be sure but it all all good, fresh, and flavorful. We especially like the chicken tacos when they are available -- there is a different "taco of the day" on the weekdays-only Happy Hour menu -- and the Margarita's are great. The Pub Salad is a meal unto itself, the burgers are good and the hand-cut French fries are great.

A popular Brunch is served from 11 am to 2 pm on weekends. The Toad is child-friendly and, of course, being a pub the beer list is awesome. When we've driven to The Toad for dinner we've sometimes parked in the shopping center lot diagonally across from the restaurant and never been ticketed in the evening.

We live in North Boulder and often see our neighbors at The Toad. The stretch of Broadway from Pearl Street north to the Boulder city limits is becoming a bit of a Mecca for quality, non-franchise restaurants and The Toad is a much-appreciated "anchor" for this new culinary scene.

title: "Authentic" keeps popping up ...
text: ... and it will help if one has a basic feel for traditional Mexican menu items. Durango is a modest, clean place with friendly service. Great for families but you can get a Mexican beer here, too, though there is no bar. I had breakfast at Durango one morning while my motorcycle was being serviced at Rocky Mountain Kawasaki, a short walk away. Free chips and salsa, good coffee, and steamy tortillas. My breakfast -- with eggs, beans, rice, salsa, and a lettuce and tomato garnish came to $12.40. I'll be back!

title: A gem
text:
If in one's mind, one can substitute palm trees for the evergreens overgrowing the patio and see a white sand beach where Coffman Street runs in front, it is easy to sip a rum punch, nosh on plantain chips and salsa, and imagine a warm evening on a Caribbean beach.

The food -- mostly seafood and chicken but also some other meats -- and service are always excellent. The wine list is small but carefully chosen.

We make the trip to Longmont from our home in Boulder a couple of times a year; it is worth the thirty-minute drive. Located in a charming vintage "Old Longmont" house, Tortugas generally has plenty of parking along Coffman Street -- don't even think about parking in the lot of the auto repair business next door -- and we've seen customers park the U.S. Post Office lot across the street after hours.

The interior of the restaurant has a homey warmth but it is a real pleasure to sit on the patio; get there towards sunset and enjoy the white lights and colored globes draped above the tables.

Highly recommended!

title: Delightfully non-commercial
text:
A beautiful, quiet spot and did I mention it is free? You can walk almost all the way to the Gardens from the central River Walk area; the last mile or so is off the River Walk so take a map or have a useful smartphone app like CityMaps2Go to navigate the last off-River Walk section.

The walk along the San Antonio River is about five miles one way so, if you don't want to walk all the way back to Central San Antonio, use a Lift or Uber app to summon a driver.

There is a charming tea house -- Jingu House Cafe -- with tables inside and out at the Tea Gardens; bento snack boxes and iced teas are refreshing. The Gardens are a welcome respite from the often-busy city center.

title: Fun, friendly, and great food
text:
Across Calle 10 Norte from Parque 28 de Julio, the park in front of the city municipal building, Kaxapa Factory does not have the best signage but it is worth the effort to discover. Don't be surprised by a wait: The cafe which only seats 35 is very popular.

The "vibe" is so good, the family operating the restaurant often breaks out into spontaneous song while cooking and serving. The kaxapas and housemade fruit drinks are excellent and healthy.

When our friends from home went down to PDC a few weeks after we visited we said "You HAVE to try this place!" They did, and they loved it. We'll all be back!

title: Nice departure from the River Walk
text:
After three days exploring the River Walk and surrounding neighborhoods, we were ready for a new experience. I was hoping to try the vegetable panini sandwich after meal after meal of Mexican food but the menu has just changed and the panini -- though listed on the website -- was no longer available.

Our server, Shelby, was friendly, smart, and efficient. Great atmosphere and good food, definitely a favorite with locals. We'll be back!

title: A step above most River Walk restaurants
text:
Wonderful ambiance, classy without being overblown. Our server Alicia was friendly, attentive, and proficient. The guests sitting at the table next to ours had the table-side guacamole service which is always fun to watch and ensures the very freshest guac; if we had not had guacamole and drinks earlier in the day we would have had the same service.

Since we were looking for a lighter dinner we both had the Citrus Spinach Salad with Fajita Chicken and glasses of Fetzer Pinot Grigio, a perfect break from the tacos, enchiladas, tamales, beans and tortillas (and, of course, Margarita's) we enjoyed so much of on the River Walk.
place: Iron Cactus Mexican Grill and Margarita Bar

title: Meh
text:
Typical pizza, nothing special. "Tastes just like Domino's" my wife said. No wine, only bottled beer (the very limited draft beer pulls were malfunctioning) and, oddly, frozen Margarita's. The side salads were adequate and the twelve-inch pizza was more than filling for the two of us.

We sat outside in the attractive-looking side courtyard which, oddly, co-housed the air conditioning units for nearby buildings; the noisy fans blew hot air over our table and throughout the courtyard.

Pizzarita's is an order-at-the-counter operation and Kendrell was friendly but otherwise service (and ambiance) were minimal.

title: Great place for an afternoon sangria
text: Peach sangria, chips, and salsa on a shady table by the river on a hot afternoon. Could it get any better?

title: Friendly, low-key cafe
text:
Just seconds from the River Walk, La Vallita Cafe is in a preserved and restored historic neighborhood that invites exploration. Friendly service and good, reasonably-priced food. Breakfast for two cost about as much as one buffet breakfast in our nearby hotel.

Highly recommended!

title: Go mid-morning and avoid the crowd
text: A wonderful and well-preserved piece of history. So real and "un-kitschy" that if I were scouting period movie locations in San Antonio, Schilo's would be on my short list. Eggs with potato pancakes and applesauce make a great breakfast.

title: World-class urban experience
text: The River Walk is up there with the best of them: Paris, Barcelona, London, New York City; the list goes on. Beautifully maintained and patrolled, it can be crowded on weekends. A plethora of good but reasonably-priced restaurants and cuisines.

title: A great afternoon
text:
We did a three-mile non-guided tour on a Monday afternoon and were the only people on the water until we met two kayakers joining the San Antonio River at the two-mile mark; they soon left us behind as they paddled swiftly downstream while we relaxed and enjoyed the varied waterfowl and shore birds.

A couple of tips: Take it slow and easy, wear a hat and sunscreen, and take a bottle of water. I wore a long-sleeve shirt under my life vest with my smartphone in one chest pocket and my wallet in the other; they started dry while my shorts got a bit wet from water in the kayak.

Next time we are in San Antonio we'd like to try the San Antonio Mission Bike Tour offered by Mission Kayak's sister company.

title: Worth searching out
text: In an unassuming location in a very average strip mall, Cuatro is a delight! Great service and excellent food. We'll be back the next time we visit Maui.

title: Now "Other Islands Caribbean Food"
text: As of mid-October 2016, the Surfing Burro has been renamed Other Islands Caribbean Food. The bright orange trailer is still in the same location.

title: Closed due to fire 10/24/16
text:
The Maui News reported Three's Bar and Grill is closed indefinitely after suffering an apparent kitchen fire early Sunday morning, October 23, 2016.

According to The News, the owners of Three's are trying to place staff in other local restaurants until Three's reopens. The paper reports that damages are estimated to be about $250,000.

title: A delightful surprise
text:
When we knew we had a five-hour evening layover before a flight to Lima, Peru we planned on dinner at DFW Airport. While DFW has the usual fast food court eateries, Pappasito's Cantina was a great "find"; it's a true sit-down restaurant with friendly and efficient service.

The Laredo Combination -- a chicken tamale, cheese enchilada, and the biggest beef taco I've ever seen -- was great and my wife's chicken enchiladas looked good as well. The large margaritas went well with the chips and fresh salsa and ensured that we would sleep soundly on our 10:15pm flight.

Should we find ourselves on a layover at DFW again, we'll be sure to return to Pappasito's.

title: Friendly family place
text:
Bright and colorful, El Toro Viejo is a roomy space on the corner of an older strip mall on South Main Street in Brigham City, not too far from the motel on the I-15 / I-84 Interstate Highway where we stayed one night on a road trip from Denver to Portland.

Service was friendly and efficient; we noticed several families with children who seemed to be having a great time. The food was not high-end gourmet food like you might expect in Santa Fe, New Mexico, but it was good, fresh, and hot. The beer was cold and prices were reasonable.

If and when we make that road trip again, we'll make a point of overnighting in Brigham City and having another dinner at El Toro Viejo.

title: Fast, friendly, efficient
text:
What is there to say about a Burger King? Like McDonald's, they are all pretty much the same. Seen one, seen 'em all.

Having said that, the Tremonton Burger King is a friendly place near the Interstate Highways with a big parking lot that is easy to navigate in an RV or with a trailer. It is clearly popular with locals yet has a good mix of travelers as well.

Food was fresh, hot, and served quickly. There are commercial truck service businesses close by so an over-the-road trucker — or an RV owner — needing a repair could hang out at the BK after refueling or while repairs were being done.

Close to the I-15 / I-84 junction with easy on and off in all directions, it is a good place for a traveler to stop for a meal. Open from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m..

title: Friendly, close to the Interstate Highways
text:
The Western Inn is a clean, friendly, quiet place close to the junction of I-15 and I-84 north of Ogden and Brigham City, Utah. We chose to stay at the Western Inn for one night during a cross-country road trip because the rates were much more affordable than those in motels closer to Salt Lake CIty.

The motel motif is, indeed, western with a great selection of cowboy and Texan items. It is kind of kitschy but great fun at the same time. Our room was clean, quiet, and had two large comfortable Barcalounger-type recliners.

The front desk was friendly and efficient. There is a Burger King next door, open from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m.. If we make that road trip again, we will not hesitate to stay at the Western Inn.
